job_title: Student Advisor in West Pasco, WA
pros: Rewarding job. Great coworkers. Get to work one on one with students
cons: Managing is terrible. Always trying to micromanage.

job_title: Campus Support Specialist in Oxnard, CA
pros: - the students for sure. I enjoy being able to talk to them on a daily basis and help them out in their career goals and aspirations -work culture. Our office is almost like a family. I enjoy how close the employees all are and are willing to help each other out - management. Personally, I have a good relationship with my superiors, and I appreciate all of their help
cons: - communication. Things can get confusing sometimes because of how quickly new employees are hired and sometimes there is a lack of communication in terms of who to go to

review_title: We work to get you to work
pros: The amazing staff at Charter College is the reason I get up in the morning. The students are amazing learners and they are the reason we are here.
cons: Sometimes there is a disconnect between departments - I would like to see more collaboration. Possibly a staff meet and greet.

pros: Great working environment. Management always pushes workers to be better.
cons: Change of management is very frequent

pros: I have the most supportive managers. The culture is amazing. I have truly found a love for financial aid and I have been blessed to work my way up in the company. There is so much room for growth and I love everyone that I get to work with.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Small campus, positive work environment, awesome faculty and staff who support each other in creating an environment that is inclusive and conducive to teaching our students the skills and knowledge they need to be successful in their chosen pathway.
cons: More in person training for certain positions is needed.

review_title: LOVE our mission, our culture and our students!
pros: I LOVE my job and am passionate helping my students achieve their education goals.
cons: Better and more efficient communication between departments could help with some disconnect and help build more trust between employees, resulting in a more productive organization.

review_title: Stellar employer with a mission for helping people improve their Lives.
pros: Everyone has a passion for helping people. We work to get people to work, but more importantly, we are the College that Cares.
cons: Don't really have any cons other than we need more students to help.

pros: Great co workers, great atmosphere, work with staff and instructors who really love the students and care about their best interest.
cons: Would love to remodel the old flooring, make the school modern looking.

job_title: Campus Manager in Canyon Country, CA
pros: Great staff that works well together and cares about the success of students.
cons: There's a lot of opportunity for more name recognition in the local community. Many don't know about Charter College.

job_title: Campus Support Specialist in Vancouver, WA
pros: Great flex schedule with awesome co-workers and popcorn.
cons: Company growth dictates the position I hold becomes full-time instead of the part-time schedule at.

pros: It was a good place to get experience in a college
cons:
high turn around rate
lack of appreciation for their reps.
Literally everyone there was soooo stressed and concerned for their job

pros: So far so good! Very helpful and competitive salary
cons: Not for you if you aren't self motivated

review_title: Loved helping students but management was shady
pros: Helping others get back to school
cons: Micromanagement is seriously an understatement

pros: Great pay, school/office environment, small campus.
cons: Out-of-date training and software, the longer you've been there the more they let you bend the rules--all they want are results.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: High wage, good co-workers and long lunch break.
cons:
150+ cold calls daily (to people who do NOT want to hear from you). High pressure from management, irregardless of the low quality leads. Unrealistic expectations of all employees (not attainable by anyone nor was attained by anyone during my tenure). This is a fear-based employment, arduous and exhausting. Co-workers made it worth it, for a time. Charter also refused to opt into the 2021 Q1 tax credit offered by the federal government for Coronavirus relief. Instead I was told I needed to "use my PTO" when I became extremely ill. Meaning, they didn't care enough to do the paperwork for their people, even at no cost to the company. I surpassed all company expectations and left for a better opportunity. Wouldn't allow me to complete 2 weeks notice (doing a favor to the company, even offering to make additional calls far beyond expectations), for no reason other than "we don't do that here." 
Overall: heartless corporate overlords, lackluster product, poor management and relentless cold calling made for an extremely poor work environment.

pros: Flexible schedule. Fun and inviting work environment.
cons: None to write down. This is really based on personal preference. I found nothing wrong with my employment or employer.

pros: hard to find a positive
cons: Micromanagement, termination with out notice or warning, low pay, little to no support from management.

job_title: Campus Support Specialist in Canyon Country, CA
pros: Easy job. Nice co workers
cons: Its really slow right now

job_title: Campus Support Specialist in Oxnard, CA
pros: Great pay, benefits and schedule
cons: No cons, great work environment

review_title: It’s kind of a mixed bag
job_title: Medical Assistant Instructor in Anchorage, AK
pros:
Time off is respected
Only work a few days a week
cons:
Organization is a revolving door of employment, people come and go all the time.

Sometimes admissions enrolls people regardless of whether or not they are a good fit

job_title: Customer Support Specialist in Wasilla, AK
pros: I enjoyed my time at charter college. The hourly rate was acceptable for the work we had to do. Supportive team and supervisors. Rarely worked longer than scheduled, never called in or worked on weekends.
cons: I don't have any cons.

pros: Enhances your skills providing educational services.
cons:
Lack of Communication
Lack of Leadership
No teamwork

pros: Pay was the only benefit.
cons:
This entire "sales oriented" company focuses on putting individuals in poor situations in copious amounts of debt to make slightly above minimum wage. Giving these students poor guidance and setting them up for a harder run at life than they had before. This company cares nothing about the individuals that work there nor the students that attend.

Directors at multiple campuses and sales offices will run you till you cannot perform any longer. Hanging your job over your head for unreachable sales goals. The pay is great, but that is the only "great" thing about this company. There is no continued training nor mentorship to better your skills and they will threaten you if they're not met. No sense of job security, with objectives changing every few weeks as the company is continuing to fail month by month. Students enrolled AKA "SALES QUOTA" was not met once in over the two years I was there.

This company is sinking and will drowned any individual that gets in its way.

Management in many offices have alcohol abuse issues and it definitely pours into the work place. Literally.

pros: Training with Nate was by far the best training I've had. Very knowledgeable and allowed me to gain the confidence I needed. He provides feedback at the moment to help the entire training group to grow.
cons: Now, this is where it goes downhill after you leave the trainer you get handed over to your assigned DOA; that doesn't really do anything. You go from someone being able to teach you anything, to a DOA that barely knows how they should manage or train. This is extremely frustrating when they are sitting in their office the entire time, while we're having our jobs hanging over our head.

review_title: Beware of corporate leader ship that changes on a daily basis
pros: The company may pay decent wages.
cons: Too many to list. Very dishonest acts, you will get terminated if you file a complaint with HR, seen it done with several in one year with very valid complaints. Very unprofessional leader ship that changes on a daily basis. As well as long-term employees went away when Covid hit and they brought in the newer staff To avoid paying senior wages.

pros: Great facility and teaching staff at the local student level.
cons:
Process takes value over the people being served.
Upper management is NOT in touch with local needs.
Constant change in process builds division over unity.

pros: At first, you will get in-depth training to get you going. You will get a lot of information in a couple of weeks. Just know they do virtual training. I was iffy at first, however, the trainer makes it fun and enjoyable. He will even set time aside to make sure you're good to go. After training, you hit the floor and start going. Expect to study and stress out at first.
cons: Stressed from quotas! Lots and lots of pressure.

pros: 1) Competitive pay 2) Outstanding support from Program Manager 3) Campus President is extremely positive 4) Working with students is highly rewarding 5) Positive work environment with outstanding co-workers 6) Flexible hours 7) Excellent support system in place for students 8) Courses are well designed and relevant for students. 9) High placement for graduates 10) Overall Charter College has adapted well to the challenges of delivering instruction during COVID.
cons: Medical insurance is good for singles but pricey to add dependents. To be fair that is the norm across most of U.S.

pros: Pay is decent. A few kind employees.
cons: Where does one begin to describe the toxic environment of this company? Dishonest, displays of bigotry and bias, absolutely no compassion. Favoritism runs rampant regardless of ones efforts and back stabbing is the norm. By far one of the most unethical companies in education. Once you start, they have no qualms with reminding you just how insignificant you are and love to keep employees worried about keeping their jobs. They will demoralize and use you. Run as fast as you can away from this corporation.

review_title: Unclear expectations and bad upper management
pros: The pay is great, and the coworkers are wonderful.
cons: Unclear expectations and bad upper management

pros: this company offers many opportunities for upward growth
cons: High turn over rate in almost all departments

pros: Great company, great culture, and wonderful staff
cons: It can be hard to engage some of the student population who attends Charter College

pros: Used to be good people & good mgmt
cons: Due to restructuring, things weren't as great. A ton of layoffs and campus closure.

job_title: College Instructor in East Wenatchee, WA
pros: The Salary is very good.
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: SHUT UP/GET out whiners not allowed!
job_title: Regional Career Services Supervisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Wow, so this is more of a rant for the fools out here trying to sully the name and point fingers. SHUT UP! Do it or Get out. We are trying to nurture, coach, and mentor students/graduates every day and chances are we are sick of attempting to do the same with you. 
You don’t like change boo woo – get out!
You don’t like our ethics – probably because you do not work as hard as we do with integrity and don’t know the industry – GET OUT!
You are afraid to speak up – Stand for something or you will fall for anything – GET OUT!
We survivors in this industry are here because we love what we do, we don’t care if accolades come or if outsiders look in and think “that bad for profit”. We watch, coach, and support our students and graduates regardless. 
You just wanted more atta boys and did get them, stop crying and GET OUT!
cons:
I will not lie, the company has some quick movements. Very agile, less communicative than I would like and that makes for an insecure staff. It is very different than prior experiences I have had. 
I will tell you something though in other companies where people felt so secure, some of them stopped pushing, stopped helping, stopped talking, and ultimately became barnacles on the boat. 
I would rather be where EVERY ore is in the water, wouldn’t you?

pros: If I had to pick a pro, it would be the pay, it was pretty good, but not worth the garbage you have to deal with.
cons: Where do I start?  Constant humiliation and hostile work environment from managers.  Posting signs all over campus telling employees to remain in their office, which were seen by fellow employees and students. They refused to allow us any breaks, forcing us to work through lunches, and would yell at us if we were caught outside of our offices.  The employees are constantly expected to hit unrealistic goals, and encouraged to lie to prospective students.  If you don't hit your enrollment goals, they question your integrity.  Management is very unprofessional, talking to employees about other employees, texting during meetings but asking their staff not to, and encouraging an environment of reporting employees to management so they are in better standing with managers.  Your job is NEVER safe.  They have a revolving door policy for employees, and will let you go for absolutely no reason.  Training is a joke.  The hardest part of the job is the part they spend the least amount of time with you on.  Management claims to provide excellent training, but in reality, they provide very little coaching afterwards to ensure you are on the right track.

pros: Charter College is my second career after several years in the K-12 Public School system. I have worked at Charter College for 5 years, now. I started as an online instructor. Within two months I was teaching both online and on my local campus. After one year I had privilege of becoming the Dean of Education and worked for a person who I describe as the best and most influential boss I had ever worked with. Another year passed and I was honored with the opportunity to serve as Campus President where I have served for the past 3 years. Charter College has been the best place I have worked in an almost 40 year career in Education. The college is serious about providing a high caliber curriculum and educational experience for our students. Placement of students in their field of study is a top priority and we do everything we can to work with students to achieve their career goals. This is not only a fulfilling place to work it is a fun place. I love change and growth, so I love working here. Charter has accelerated programs that move at a fast and demanding pace. It keeps a person on their toes.
cons: Change can be frustrating for many people. The pace is fast. The school is demanding. You will not likely get rich working here.

pros: Nice college, nice dorms, nice students
cons: horrible hours, works u to death, terrible base pay

review_title: Make a Change this is a real thing,
job_title: Lead Dental Assistant Instructor in Fife, WA
pros: Great pay, good benefits, great staff.
cons: Need to put money into marketing. Just do it!

review_title: Could be a good place to work
pros: The instructors are passionate about what they do. The campus was very clean.  Helping students achieve their dreams is an amazing intrinsic reward.
cons: In admissions we made 100+ phone calls a day.   I was directed to call numbers that I knew where wrong to try and get a lead out of it.  After that,  and a few other "creative" ways of lead generation, I became disengaged.  I still made my goals ethically, but could not get back on board.  I lost respect for my director and that is why I was fired.  Contrary to HR's response to another review.  I had good numbers.  Of course when I was let go, the numbers thrown at me where not even close to what I really had achieved.  I didn't bother to fight for my position, the decision had been made for me.  I couldn't continue to work for a director that was shady.  I am grateful that I was fired, now I have a position that does not stress me out.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Paychecks are stable and the company's use of technology is really causing it to grow quickly!  Compared to other schools, there is some freedom to put your personality into the interview process, which is nice.  Good people & processes in every department try to help the students overcome challenges to succeed & graduate.  The technology is really amazing.
cons: The SLC location is new and growing, so management is figuring out what works and what doesn't. High turnover, but not unlike many sales positions. High pressure can be exhausting & stressful. This place is not for people with health conditions!

pros: I have worked for Charter College for 4 years and absolutely love what I do. I get to work with a great group of professionals who truly care about our students and graduates and who see their success as their own. There are a lot of opportunities for employees to move up, as our company is growing.
cons: As a company, Charter College is constantly evolving; and if you are not prepared to be flexible and grow then this is not the company for you.

review_title: Fine for a pit-stop while you seek a better job!
pros: There are some good people who work there.  They strive to use the latest technology.  If you are able to negotiate a decent salary you will show up for work.  Decent benefit package offered.  Free online skill courses and education discount,
cons: Constant changes in policy/programing.  They have a very high turn over rate in employees. I personally saw 8 employees leave or get fired. Including Dean oAdmissions and Campus President. They are profit driven and have high pressure to make unreasonable enrollment goals every 5 weeks.  Campuses come and go quickly,  They micro manage too much.  They say they want independent thinkers to help them think out of the box or to offer ways to improve how they do things but if you question at all expect to get a pink slip.

job_title: Student Records Specialist in Anchorage, AK
pros: The hours were pretty flexible and I didn't feel like I was being micromanaged. Most of my co-workers were pretty awesome people. Pay was decent.
cons: I left because I felt that the company was unethical and didn't want to be a part of that. I didn't feel like they really were looking out for the best interest of the students or the employees. Most of the unethical stuff came from admissions, like trying to push people through that weren't really eligible just to get their numbers up. Then when I tried to block it and follow the RULES, I was made to look like the bad guy. They ended up firing my replacement and eliminating the position a few months after I left only to open it up again offering $4/hr more than what I was getting. They do that a lot, most recently the campus Executive Assistants. One of them was told she could stay with the company in admissions if she fired the incumbent. Yeah.

pros: When I started off working for Prospect Education, it was known as one of the best companies I worked for. Great management, benefits, fun working environment, and always recognized for my hard work. Great coworkers I can now call friends!
cons: Employees are punished for the company’s lack of financial stability and inconsistent/poor management. Due to the company losing money, employees are now treated less than and all of our hard work that was done yesterday, the previous month, or previous quarter is discarded....even if we made/maintained our department goals. The CEO is extremely greedy and insensible! Not only has he humiliated us by this new "tsunami" thing he has going, which gave most of us hope the company will pick back up, BUT we will all be out of jobs in January 2015 with no severance to show some type of appreciation for ALL of our hard work we have provided towards this company. Some of us have been loyal to this company for years and this is what we get...a SLAP IN THE FACE!

review_title: Stay Away!!! This is a Sinking Ship!!!
job_title: Career Services Officer in South Jordan, UT
pros: Decent pay. Benefits are okay at best. Good Work-Life Balance.
cons:
Accrediting body (ACICS) no longer accredited by the Federal Department of Education. So, it's only a matter of time before this place goes under. Management is horrendous. They let go of some of our top performers, while promoting someone completely incompetent to manage a team (seriously, this person is completely useless). Their decision(s) to keep someone are/were based more on personal feelings. I am actively searching for a new job because I can no longer stand to be here. 
Management changes their minds day-to-day about what they want you to focus on. They truly have no idea what they are doing. There is such high turnover. Outside of the massive layoffs that happened in June, I think about 13-15 people have left in the past 6 months. A number of those just left. No 2 weeks notice. They recognized what a joke this place is. Please do yourself the favor and do not work here. Hopefully this place will be put out of it's misery sometime soon.

pros: The mission of Charter College is geared to helping adult students set positive career goals and to give them the support and tools they need to be successful. Not only practical skills but also the soft skills that make or break a person's employment experience. I feel they do an admirable job. I felt like we provided a valuable service to the community and put many people to work in roles that make a difference.
cons: Looking back at my experience there, it would be nice if the CEO and Human Services had the bravery to approach what they see as unsatisfactory behavior in an open, constructive and forthright manner. Their approach is not that at all. I have to say that I respect and honor them for their work generally, but solving problems with employees is a superior way to improve rather than to fire and hire new employees.

review_title: Got a whole lot better later...
job_title: Admissions Representative in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: As of July of 2013, the company hired back two superstar employees in the Canyon Country location.  Both the President and the Director of Admissions are phenomenal, fair, and very much hands on.  The CEO made the decision to eliminate a layer of management that brought him closer to the soldiers in the field.  These changes made a huge difference in company culture.
cons: The admissions rep is basically a sales job with no real incentive.  Well the incentive is a salary, benefits, and a desire to keep your job.  Due to Title IV, private colleges are not allowed to pay you commission.  So they focus on the metrics that you have to hit, but motivation is with the "stick."  At least that's how it was before the management change.  Now, they are much more supportive and know how to motivate constructively.

review_title: Nothing but BAD and I mean BAD, Very Unprofessional
pros: Honesty None and I can only say I met two people there that I still call friends. Besides that they are a horrible company to work for.
cons: Name it - Micromanaged, it's all about the numbers and making the stakeholders, President and Director of Admissions a bonus! They don't care about the students and will ring them in with bad financial aid plans. Got so tired of hearing - " Why didn't you enroll them", "What could you have done better"?  Honestly, I have morals and ethics and when you are a top producer, as I was, you don't make up false accusations about a person, which is what they do to get rid of people.  They are just dishonest and career services is a big fat joke! They don't help you at all they send craigslist posts saying that's helping. STAY AWAY FROM THIS COMPANY

review_title: Good starter job, don't expect to stay here long
job_title: Technology Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Good people, making a difference with students' lives, decent pay. Good entry level job. Small IT department means good exposure to advanced tools such as Active Directory, Google Apps, Citrix, etc. 
Some project work.
cons:
At this for-profit school, some students should have never been allowed to enroll. 
Management is very shortsighted - short term decisions.
The computers that they buy for administrative personnel are so cheap and slow that they can't play Internet video without stuttering. Total cost of ownership is high because they buy off brands, and then management seems surprised when they start dropping like flies. 
Poor standards and poor IT centralization - dozens of different computer models in use around the company means software imaging development is done at each campus branch. User ID move/add/change is done locally as well. No central support team other than data center/central applications. 
Company seems to lurch from one crisis to another, dropping and hiring people at every turn.

review_title: When everything is handed to you, it's hard for others to be successful
job_title: Admissions in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I enjoyed most of my coworkers, but as it comes to be it looks like no one was truly a team player.
cons: I remember keeping track of how many walk ins, and interviews of MY OWN, that were given away to the other team by the Assistant Director. And as I reflect back, the people who were offered the at home positions are the ones that were handed the walk ins, and live leads. It's hard to be successful when you dispute most of your leads, and when there's someone that calls in or walks in, and it's handed to the same person each time, that's irritating. I am baffled and how unfair the work place was, and I worked just as hard as everyone else. I guess the people that got to stay must have really kissed behind to be handed all of those interviews. Definitely unfair to judge when higher management doesn't see how the work place really was run.

review_title: No longevity with employees, high turnover should be a clue to management
job_title: Admissions Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: -pretty decent pay, and loved my co workers
cons: -management is very over bearing, extremely micro managed, and numbers are all that matters. I ended up quitting but during my time at charter I saw the salt lake office shrink from 40~ reps down to 10. They fire people like it's going out of style, and even fired someone while he was at the hospital during his wife's labor. People are very stressed because there is 0 job security and constant firing with no notice. There used to be 3 assistant directors of admissions and they ended up demoting the two better ones and kept the one who got the best numbers even though it was terrible for moral and unpopular with all employees.

review_title: Good place to work, advance skills and change lives
pros: I enjoy helping others and the recruitment process.  Our office is a fun place to work, and we have very bright and creative people on our campus.  We work hard to achieve great results for our department, the campus and the student.  I've learned a lot about communication and overcoming obstacles and challenges in my position.  We all share a lot of responsibility which is great if you prefer a fast paced environment.
cons: Some may not appreciate the short recruitment cycle.  I like working in a fast-paced environment and work well under pressure, so I thrive on it.  Others tend to find out quickly if it's not a fit for them and don't last.

review_title: Career Services Officer : South Jordan , UT
job_title: Career Services Officer/Trainer in South Jordan, UT
pros: I was hired by the director with whom I ended up having a strong working relationship .  She was always patient , approachable and supportive.  I later reported to a different supervisor, a senior CSO, who had the same attributes.  They both strived to make the working environment better and to assist with training/professional development.  The director that hired me even offered to give me a professional reference if I ever need it--class act.  Even the "boss' boss" who worked in my same office was very cool and approachable--she's very positive.  She supported me and listened to my suggestions.   I love that they foster teamwork and have monthly teambuilding/social activities.  I would recommend this employer. It's a great gig.
cons: People come and people go in all organizations...

review_title: They have thrown their ethics out the window.
pros: When you actually make a difference in a students life when they finally find a job.
cons: There is a lot of backstabbing from managers and other employees. The amount of enrollments into their programs is flooding the market which results in students $40,000 in debt and unable to find a job. The company is only worried about how much money it is making and not about it students (the individuals that fund the machine) or employees. If any one has a back bone and speaks up for the students or their business ethics then they are sent down the road. There is too much change which results in layoffs about once a month. Also there is very few employees that make it to one or even two years before they are let go.

pros:
I have had a very different experience at Charter College than some on this feedback site. I have been a team member for over a year and have seen both tremendous growth and the opportunities that follow. That is what makes the job exciting and fuels my passion for helping others.  
I am proud to say that I work for Charter College. We are a company who is laser focused on doing what is right for the students and employees. 
We have a very committed leadership team that doesn’t expect any more from us than what they themselves, are willing to give. This truly is a team effort!
cons: It would be nice to start the 401k earlier than a year. Even without the company matching, it’s a great way for us to save.

job_title: Executive Recruiter in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: While I was at Charter College (Prospect Education) in the student Services department, we had a great team there that had a lot of success in assisting the graduates in finding positions in their field of study.
cons: Lack of Leadership at the head of the office and also in the school. Just before I left a new President took over the reigns at the college....and the spiral started. I have since learned that the office we were housed out of has been closed and ALL of the Student Service employees at that location have either left or been laid off, except the head of the office who sat behind a desk and had no interaction with the staff except to let them go. Who is assisting the student? Who is keeping the students interest first in helping them find positions?The students have to be frustrated with the lack of help.

review_title: School will be closed soon im sure. dont waste your time.
pros: great entry salary, nice office, no weekends.
cons: the School is NOT ACCREDITED they lie to students and say it is their credits will NEVER transfer. the school itself is a joke there are NO BOOKS for the students even though the tuition is thru the roof. the school is always empty as it should be. you will be making ALOT of outbound calls you are basically a high paid telemarketer you are expected to call students on a DAILY basis sometimes three times A DAY. very cold environment to work in ,upper management is very dishonest and not trust worthy. there is NO TRAINING but very high expectation to preform.  no one wants to go to this school. most of the students are felons low income or have mental challenges. the "president" is essentially an over paid chair ornament.  layoffs are very common.  firings are even more common. if you have no soul you will fit right in.

review_title: Great place to work; lots of opportunity for advancement!
pros: I started at Charter College in an entry-level position and was promoted after five months. Our campus president is dedicated to employee growth. At Charter College you have the chance to further develop existing skills and cultivate new skills ranging anywhere from communication to technology. Charter has a terrific company culture; everyone on campus operates as a team. Additionally, Charter College is dedicated to student success. The resources available to students astounds me! I used to work at a University; hands-down I prefer Charter College! Charter is innovative with student-centered classrooms. I couldn't ask for a better job!
cons: As with all schools, "difficult" students will always be problematic. Sometimes it's easy to become overwhelmed by students that don't show up for class, or complete their homework--but that's education!

pros: Telecommuting and the flexibility of setting your own hours with a fixed time for lectures..
cons:
Re-post as last time my position was incorrect (had the default of Loan Specialist) so as requested I my position was online instructor.

Classes just stopped being offered without notice and was told that ground instructors were getting the online classes.

Just to refresh memory, asking questions appeared to "Rock the Boat."

pros: The Students at Charter College are dedicated and devoted to change their lives. Watching them grow into professionals and being a part of that is the most amazing feeling.
cons: You never know what to expect next. After working there for awhile, you will start to feel like a "Corporate Puppet". The Campuses are not allowed to build their own community. The campuses are now all run by people in Reno and the feeling of a "Family" unit is nonexistent. Management is horrible! There is no regard to peoples feelings, thoughts, or personal issues. Employees are treated and manipulated like robots. If you do not act like a robot you will be thrown into the junk pile.

review_title: The most rewarding job! PROUD to be a part of this company!
pros: Extremely rewarding job, Excellent compensation and benefits, Fantastic upward mobility options, Team focused, Student focused, Fast paced and exciting work environment and integrity as the foundation!
cons: If you aren't flexible and willing to grow and change in an ever present changing world, this likely isn't the company for you. If integrity, hard work, and a commitment to supporting the students through their education and into the workforce is not your cup of tea, you may want to look elsewhere. If working for a corporation is not your gig, Charter is not for you.

review_title: Worst company I have worked for
job_title: Academic Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The pros that I can say for this job was that I did not have to work on weekend and I was able to pay my bills.
cons: This was the worst experience I have ever had in my career. Leaving was the best decision I have ever made in my life. Upper management does nothing but lie to you about the company it self and also how the care about you. This company does not put there employees first at all and has no respect , ethics and values! They hide everything and the turn over should speak volumes. The only people who stay in the company is super management and they need to Reevaluate who and what the problem is because the people they are firing which I wasn’t one of them but the many they have since I saw aren’t either. It might be them.

review_title: The pay is great, the environment will leave you feeling dirty
pros: Great pay. Some of the leadership is outstanding and really went out of their way to help grow their team. Nice being able to communicate with students over skype and make a difference in their lives (hopefully for the better..)
cons: Sometimes a toxic environment. Lots of pressure to enroll prospective students who may not be the best fit for the Charter programs.. I doubt the efficacy of their programs as well, read the reviews. Spontaneous layoffs if the lead forecast does not match up with reality. Charter college is sincerely a money driven environment and they won't hesitate to can you if you don't soak up their shark like mentality towards enrolling anyone and everyone.

pros: The love of teaching and helping students is what kept me there.
cons: My paycheck was often incorrect. Different duties offered different payrates but none were itemized on the paycheck. I made sure to keep my own records. When compared to my check, 70% of the time out was wrong and I always felt like I was begging for money. On a few occasions, payrates would change with no notice. It wasn't until after the work was complete and the paycheck was incorrect that I was notified of the change in pay. I felt there was no one higher up the chain to go to.

pros: Fantastic students and amazing coworkers. Beautiful lab equipment and facility. Absolutely love teaching blended courses. Love seeing my students get hired!! Very much enjoy the investment in current market technology and being able to teach that to my students. Great choice of textbook with online resource to go with it. Love having the freedom to choose my own guest speakers. Great PAC meeting board members. Productive curriculum review/program revamp meetings this year. Great new program manager.
cons: Low enrollment. High turnover. While I am very sad things are coming to an end at Lynnwood, from a business standpoint, closing the campus makes sense. I hope to continue with Charter at a different location should an opportunity arise. It has been a fantastic ride.

review_title: Locally familial, Nationally tyrannical with fleeting ethics
pros:
The campus leadership at the local level was incredible.  
The admissions team was the best in the company as well as an incredible family to work with. 
Management allowed us to make the right decisions for our potential students.  
The pay was good for the last year that I was there.
cons: The upper management is tyrannical  and insulting to their employees.   Unrealistic expectations and emotionally fueled and aggressive attacks upon the character of their employees seems to be the way that they choose to operate.  I used to be a huge advocate of the CEO until I discovered the nature of his bureaucratic  iron fist.  Though I consider myself an incredibly intuitive individual, I had no idea that he chose to smile in your face and defame behind your back.  All promotions were politically based, zero came from skill.  In fact, many of the promotions from one campus in particular were in the interest of defusing a scandal.  All of the people promoted were female.  Management operates in a completely dismissive manner.  A year ago, they cut the pay for admissions representatives by way of an email (we weren't important enough for a meeting...).  This pay cut was so catastrophic that the most tenured member of our team lost $30,000 annually and had 2 weeks to prepare for such a catastrophic pay cut.  Not even a month later during a quarterly meeting, the former CEO bragged that his average annual bar tab was more than the meager salary that he had just cut his admissions reps to.  Over the course of my 3 years at the Vancouver campus I watched 43 people either be fired or quit (predominantly fired).  The campus is practically a rotating door.

review_title: I LOVE working for Charter College
pros:
I have been in several different positions since I've been with Charter.  I keep learning and I keep growing.  I started out as an Administrative Assistant, moved on to Admissions Assistant, Student Success Officer and the Director of Student Success.  Well that position changed due to some restructuring of how things are done.  But look, I'm still here!  Now I'm working as a Career Service Officer and am looking to keep on learning and keep on moving. 

 This company is not sitting back and letting life happen to them they are moving forward and thinking ahead and setting up a strong foundation.  Every move they have made has been for the students, and making it easy for them to fit changing their lives into their schedules.  By offering blended learning and online classes and support.  Some of the reviews I have read just make me shake my head.  I for one am proud to be here amid the changes and to be part of something wonderful.
cons: If you are afraid of change or progress then this probably isn't the place for you.  They do not look for people who want to sit and mosey through life.  This company is alive and you have to be ready to go for it.  A great sense of humor and a can do attitude and belief in what  you are doing is all you need.  Is it all roses and rainbows?  No, but where in life can you find that?  You have to make your choice every day to live the life you want and be the person you want to be.

pros: Flexible hours. Get to work with students. Able to work independently. Like being able to look for ways to improve the classes for students in an on-line environment.
cons: Not always easy to communicate in an on-line environment but this is part of the challenge. Pay can always be better. They do provide medical benefits as long as we hit the new magic number of 30 hours, which is nice; as well as a 401(K) plan. This is appreciated.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Pasco, WA
pros: I enjoy getting to help students change their lives. Many come in from great struggles, and it is so rewarding to see them at graduation and even afterwards when they have become gainfully employed in the field they received their degree. I love my co-workers...at the campus, we have a really fun atmosphere.
cons: There are a lot of changes, but with the right attitude, this could be considered a pro. :)

job_title: Admissions Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I was able to find an actual career somewhere else.  This place is for people who want to worry about their positions daily.  Being able to quit was one of the happiest days of my life.
cons: They hire on a whim and fire on a whim, they really have no idea what they are doing.  They change their business plan constantly, because its shaky.  With acics hopefully getting shut down, maybe it will topple charter too.  The CEO is completely self absorbed and he has his side kick that many believe may worship satan.  Stay away from this place.

job_title: Education Classroom Coordinator in Reno, NV
pros: The people you work with on campus are great, and most of the students are dedicated to their program.
cons: Benefits are minimal, long hours, and lack of training.  Positions are eliminated without warning. Student retainment is more of a priority than the quality of learning.

pros: My co-workers! We are all very close and chat throughout the day to keep each other going. It's like a Family. We have each other's backs!
cons: Our Campus President has bright pink hair and wears short leather skirts. Not the way to set an example of a dress code, though she will look at us side-ways if we wear something she doesn't like.  They fire employees with no explanation at all. The morale is very low and almost all of us are looking for other jobs!

job_title: Career Services Advisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
I love my coworkers, but we all feel like we are taking advantage of the students that are borrowing huge sums of money to go here. 

(The school should be unaccredited and audited.)
cons:
I feel dirty working here everyday. 

The students are so happy when they come in and I know 1/10, even after exhausting all resources, will get a job with the degree we provided. 

It should be self evident that we don't provide a good education when we won't even interview people for a job if they were educated by us!!!!!

review_title: The best company I have worked for
job_title: Education Loan Specialist in Oxnard, CA
pros: Great environment!  Employees treat one another with respect.  We are all very passionate about helping students advance their career goals.  Upper management is always open to feedback from staff and faculty.  Contribution and collaboration is highly encouraged.
cons: Sometimes, there is a lot of change so you have to be quick and keep up.  Recent restructuring at some campuses has resulted in staffing changes.  But, change brings growth which is a pro, not a con.

review_title: There’s more respectable companies out there
job_title: Admissions Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The people I work with (besides management)
cons: Just about everything working for charter is a con. Bosses are micro-management style. Fire and hire kinda type of company. Benefits are even the best. The pay is decent but there’s a lot of other companies out there that have better benefits and pay. Also being a parent and having to deal with situations you can’t foresee- they punish you for choosing your family over work. And I’m talking small situations like kids are sick and you need to miss one day.

review_title: Truly, how does Charter afford unemployment insurance?
pros: The pay and benefits are good for the area. The work that I did was relatively simple.  Coworkers are friendly. Free coffee. Clean work environment.
cons:
I was employed by Charter College for a year and a half. Although most would consider this a brief amount of time, at Charter, a company with an incredibly high turnover, it is a period akin to being a senior employee.  Caution to current and future employees to not get too secure in their roles. Most walk into work worried that it is their last day. It’s difficult being “Susie Sunshine” coming to work each day under these circumstances, but those who do not fall in line with a smile are asked to leave. This is not a career for rebels. Positions are easily added/dissolved without much thought. When my position was dissolved, the CEO invited us into a meeting room and explained that he came to the decision while lounging out on a beach. Literally. He let us know that we were recruited into another role that day or, if we refused to accept, we were to leave. Business is not personal but it does require tact, which the CEO unfortunately lacks. He touts his drug related youthful indiscretions at company meetings, openly discriminates younger employees* and encourages a sycophantic work culture. 
The new position was offered with the promise of training, coaching, and higher pay. Despite reservations, a job is better than no job. I held the role for less than a month and was asked to leave during the first week of formal training for “not being a good fit.” With no workflow and limited understanding of how to manage my time, I was already one foot out of the door.  
 This situation is not new to Charter. Every end of the Quarter brings more layoffs, more hack plans to improve retention. During my employment with Charter, my job description went through 2 revisions and 1 title change. By April, 20+ employees had been laid off. After this particular layoff session, the CEO stated that would be the last major layoff planned for the year of 2016. He should run for president with that kind of candor.  Upper management handles bleeding expenditures like amateurs, recklessly throwing new protocols and teams at problems that should be fixed at the system level. Watch out for the end of August!
Consideration for the students is minimal. They are treated like numbers.  
*HR- When your CEO openly states that “millennials lack work ethic” and “no skirt can be too short” at company-wide meetings,and there is no reprimanding you do not build the rapport of a safe, reliable place for employees to bring their concerns regarding ageism, racism, sexism and sexual harassment. You do quite the opposite, actually.

pros: You don't just work at Charter College alone. You become a family with your department that does not stop once no longer employed with this company. The coworkers  are the best part. I should mention that the relationships with the students are great as well.
cons: Watching the dreams of students wash out to see by the tsunami that is Charter College and knowing that a student has no chance of ever becoming what they came to school for. Having to scrub the unethical feeling off after a hard day of work.

pros: Better than Average Pay, clean front office, friendly work staff
cons: Constant feeling of micromanagement, bad benefits, when times are tough not much help is provided, heavy workload for one position

job_title: Admissions Representative in Canyon Country, CA
pros: Pay is descent but doesn't last for long as they have high turn over rate.
cons: Leadership is horrible. Campus  President Raeleen V.  is out of date and out of touch with the needs of the students.  constant negative feedback to its employees bringing them down. School location is in a strip mall. There is no personal growth every time you try to go above and beyond they tell you to just stick to your job.

review_title: Excellent people company. This company really looks out for its employees. Working there was very satisfying.
pros: Profit-oriented education with a heart, not only for its students (customers), but its employees as well. Excellent opportunity for personal growth and an overall feeling of value as an employee.
cons: Nothing comes to mind as a real negative for working at Charter College.

pros: The pay rate is great but not worth the chastisement of management. The admissions representatives at the Vancouver campus pour their heart and souls into helping the students. Good work life balance.
cons: Worst management of my entire life. No job security. Will fire anyone at random regardless of performance. My manager snooped in my office and found I was looking for other employment. She called me into her office and tried to get me to stay, but said that if I didn't, to give her plenty of notice to find someone to fill my spot. Today I e-mailed her my 3 WEEKS notice to be nice and professional. I deliberated for a couple weeks whether I should give notice because they're known to do things like this but I decided to take the high road. A couple hours later, said manager and the managers boss came into my office and terminated me on the spot. They hovered in my office and made me clean it out, they escorted me out of the office not allowing me to say goodbye to any of my coworkers. They were acting like I got fired rather than put a courtesy of 3 WEKS NOTICE in. I currently had the head of tech support investigating my manager because late one night I heard her saying a bunch of horrible things about me to the new VP of admissions through the thin walls. The next morning I came in and someone had logged into my computer! I doubt the investigation will continue now. As soon as I was removed from the building, I was alerted that they were in my office deleting my files. They didn't even allow me the time to email myself the resignation letter for proof to get unemployment. This is the worst place I've ever worked. I made the company $500,000 in the last 4 weeks yet they continue to treat everyone like garbage. The admissions reps care about the student but all the management cares about is a buck.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Canyon Country, CA
pros: This job really provides me with the opportunity to help those who come from lower economic backgrounds and not many options when it comes to higher education to have a career in a respectable field. To see value in their life. To see a kid with no idea of how they were ever going to go to college, let alone graduate succeed in life has truly been a blessing to me.
cons: The company used to stand for something. It once had integrity and cared about the students as well as the employees. I am a current employee and have witnessed first hand how Charter College has treated it's students like cash cows. Having them pay higher tuition while we continually take away the things they need to learn their craft. We no longer offer new books. The dental students no longer have a dental lab. They have cut the hours for instructors several times. Our Vocational Nursing students no longer have the facilities they need to prepare them for the world they will embark on. Add to that the fact that now Mike Dawson has been making policy up as he goes along. Employees have continually worked hard and loyally for Charter College despite these changes and now only to be told that not only will many lose their jobs in the coming month but Mike Dawson will be taking away bonuses that we worked hard for. Bonuses that were promised to us. I understand business and am no neophyte, so when I see a company cut hours, sell off dentals labs, and raise tuition that they are suddenly cash poor. I never thought that I would say this but I would Never recommend anyone to work for this company. I am now ashamed to say that I do.

pros: The people on my team were fantastic and they leave you alone on the weekends.
cons:
They have a race problem, plain and simple. When I worked there, I was told by an authority figure that the way my natural hair grew was "too intense" for students and I was asked to "bring it in" so I would be more palatable. This administrator told me that there were students who were expressing discomfort about my appearance and specifically my hair. He later denied that students said anything to my direct supervisor, and I was told that it was a miscommunication, but the fact of the matter was that I was a black man with long hair who was asked to change my appearance because it was making people uncomfortable. That is not a positive work environment, and I would have expected so much more from a school that caters largely to low-income students of color.

While I was there, there was also an instructor who would come to us with complaints about her students of color that were blatantly prejudiced in nature. One student in particular who she made complaints about ended up dropping, and it was my job to try and convince the student to stay in an environment where he was being discriminated against. I brought my concerns to my boss as well as hers. In response to my complaint about the instructor, the same white man who told me my hair was "too intense" came to my office and assured me that Charter was an institution that respected and cherished diversity. They, like so many other institutions across this country, will tell you that they love diversity in one breath and disparage you for who you are in the next. 

I wasn't planning on saying anything about this, but with everything going on in America right now and so many people of color coming forward with their stories of workplace discrimination I feel I have a responsibility to put this out there. If you are black, indigenous, a person of color, LGBT+, etc. and thinking about working at somewhere like Charter, keep looking. You deserve better experiences than the one I had, and there is a place out there for you that respects you for who you are. 

To close, I'm sure there are many employees of color at Charter who have never experienced any kind of discrimination and that's wonderful for them. Even so, my experience happened and my experiences at Charter College matter. Charter College can insist that they value diversity until they're blue in the face, but you can't love diversity and allow discriminatory staff and administration to continue without consequences. That's not love, that's lip service.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Canyon Country, CA
pros: The faculty, staff and students are the very best part to working for Charter. Charter knows that the best way to get their staff to work extra hard for less money than they deserve is to hire very caring and loving people,not always the most qualified or professional.  Even though I no longer work for the company, I take away several quality friendships from both students and coworkers.
cons: Where do I start? First of all, Charter College is so shortsighted. They will eliminate positions across all campuses if it means they can save money for a short time. They do not consult with the people directly affected before they make dramatic changes. Also, the turn over rate is deplorable and makes the school look unprofessional when students don't know who to go to for answers. Even worse than that, students don't know where offices are most of the time. I had a position that dealt closely with the students and I moved offices 3 times in 10 months. It made it very difficult for students to find me. Another difficulty with working at Charter was due to having so many bosses. I had 1 or 2 on campus supervisors and another off campus corporate boss to account to. They each assign projects with deadlines and expectations and they each think they are the most important. Finally, I always carried around guilt for the students and the debt they were amassing. Charter is extremely expensive and often the courses do not equip students to make the maximum money in their fields. For example, Dental Assisting students are only trained to be DAs. They are lucky to make 10$ after graduation. It is only after they take an exam to become a Registered Dental Assistant that they have the potential to command more money. The school is not transparent when it comes to explaining that students will still need to pay and apply to be an RDA themselves.

pros: Great coworkers, great pay, work/life balance. Opportunities for advancement for those that want to climb the ladder.
cons: It used to be a lack of communication from top down with regard to changes.  We agree with change, it's just helpful to understand Corporate's reasoning for it.  This has recently improved, including communication from the COO explaining our centralization processes and why they were implemented.

review_title: Charter College and Its Ship of Fools
job_title: Career Services Advisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Absolutely none; I mean I guess working here was better than having the Zika virus.
cons:
Charter CEO Michael Dawson is like that crazy uncle of yours who claims he has proof that President Barack Obama wasn’t born in the United States.  Dawson is an ultraconservative fraudster who will tell you pointedly that he doesn’t want the government meddling in his affairs, and this is most likely because his affairs are highly unethical and probably flat-out illegal.  It’s no surprise that Charter College is in serious danger of losing its accreditation considering the reckless manner in which Dawson and his group of executive officers conduct themselves both publicly and privately.  While working there, I was appalled daily by the lack of leadership, professionalism, and integrity that was put on for public display.  The college, its curriculum, and its management team are all equally laughable.  The unstated goal of Charter College is to bilk as much money from as many students nationwide before the Feds catch on and shut it all down.  A student with a Charter College degree has about as much leverage in the workforce as a pimple-faced teenager who attended McDonald’s prestigious Hamburger University.  

I worked in Charter’s Salt Lake City administrative center (briefly located in a shady strip mall next to an equally shady Dollar Store) for three months before mercifully being offered a much higher paying job that better matched my qualifications.  The second I got off the phone after receiving this employment offer, I submitted my resignation effective that very moment.  I probably squealed my tires pulling out of the parking lot in what I can only describe as a feeling of euphoric relief.  For anyone reading this review and thinking about starting a career with Charter College, I have the following words of advice: Don’t.  Run.  Stay unemployed.  Trust me, the threat of homelessness and potential starvation are both better options than working on this Island of Misfit Toys.

I know Mike Dawson will respond with some garbage about an inflated 90% satisfaction rate among employees or me having "an ax to grind," but neither of those statements are true.  The fact that well over half of all Charter College reviews on Glassdoor discuss a lack of honesty, integrity, and professionalism within its leadership group speaks volumes as to what kind of ship Mike Dawson is captaining.  Luckily, though, this Ship of Fools has already torn its hull wide open and is now taking on water ...

pros: If you find the right people, they are truly the reason why you stay longer than you should. Students are very friendly, and the pay is decent. For the CEO, never had a bad thought about him. Always seemed genuinely nice to employees. Also, I enjoyed Charter College as a student so I wanted to come back and work for them. The beginning of my career was great, but then the main people began to go.
cons: The biggest con would have to be the management here at the Pasco campus. I have been accused of things that I didn't even do and when I try to explain myself, I instantly get shut down and told that I am wrong. It's extremely frustrating because all I want to do in this career is grow, but my manager is holding me back. My manager even told me to come to them if I have issues, I would bring up an issue and I was again told I was wrong. At this job, I feel defeated. No matter how hard you work at this campus, it will never feel good enough. My job doesn't even consist of making the company money, and they will still treat you like you are an idiot. I have gone to the Campus President and even HR, but I felt there is nothing I could do to make the situation better. Please be wary when applying to this campus, know who you can trust.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: They offered reasonable wages and commission plan. The benefits were subpar but had some, nonetheless.
cons: They encourage you to push applicants into any program if they don't qualify for the more challenging programs like LVN and pharm tech. They truly desire sales people, not admission counsellors. The students are basically convinced to take on debt of great amounts without any true financial counseling. There have been cases where marginal scores were altered to fill up the 50 seat LVN class starts. This school and staff are unethical!

review_title: Don't work here. Unless you like being degraded.
pros: My co workers are pretty cool, I mean what's left of them. The cool people have either been fired or they quit because of management here in Pasco, WA.
cons: Management here is pretty terrible. I have never felt so disrespected in my life. We are constantly talked down to and our jobs in admissions are constantly being threatened. In one of the comments Mr. CEO said "Over the last 5 years employees responded on average 90% of the time that they would recommend a friend to work for Charter College and this holds true at the Pasco campus as well. We think that speaks for itself.", HMM I would believe that if the survey was taken from an Admissions rep with in the first couple weeks of employment. During the last year over 10 Admissions rep's have come and gone. A direct quote from management in a meeting last week was " we have two new reps starting on Monday and I know that sounds weird because I have hired a lot". Well maybe you wouldn't have to hire a lot if you treated your team better. Seriously MR. CEO or anyone in HR who is posting on his behalf, really look into what's going on here in Pasco. I like the job, I like my co-workers, it's management within Admissions that I cannot stand. And obliviously it's not just me or 3 people would not have quit in the past month.

pros: I was employed as an Adjunct Instructor, from 2008-2014.  Due to state tax laws for Tennessee, Charter College had to refuse my continued employment.  They were gracious to say that they hated losing me and offered a reference letter, explaining the situation so future employers would understand the situation.
cons: I have nothing negative to share about this employer--they were very good to me!

job_title: Medical Instructor in East Wenatchee, WA
pros: Small enough to have regular interaction with all the students.  On-line and in-class instruction and assignments are well structured and user-friendly.
cons: Entry level training, which limits the teaching of deeper concepts.  Some course assignments requiring essay responses that do not have enough instructor resources ascribed in the grading template.

pros: You help change lifes.  Watching students graduate and then go on to work is the most wonderful thing.  I have seen homeless people get back on the feet.
cons: Just when you get comfortable something changes but that happens all thoughout life.

pros: The hourly wage is the only thing good about working there.
cons: All this place cares about is making money. They don't care about the employees what's so ever. Your day to day sales goals are so ridiculously high your fired before you even start. No team effort going on at Charter, it's everyone for themselves.

pros:
-Excellent Communication from President to staff/faculty
-Exciting and diverse students to work with 
-Everyone seems to really like there job and the people they work with 
-We get to laugh a lot and have fun while changing students lives
cons: -At times it can be stressful but honestly, what isn't stressful about a job?

review_title: They train you as far as the position goes, but cannot be candid about things going on in your personal life.
pros: Great pay, working with prospective students and helping have a hand in molding their future is rewarding.
cons: You do your job exceptionally well, and get let go with no warning.

pros: Good Pay. good equipment..  nice facility
cons: Everything from, poor communication to unattainable expectations and the amount of managerial turnover and the lack of respect for the incoming students.

review_title: The Worst Company I have ever worked for - EVER!!!
pros: My coworkers and students were all fabulous! Still friends with them all!
cons: Back stabbing, manipulative liars and they are dishonest to the tee!

review_title: Best job I've had, lots of room to grow
pros:
Overall positive atmosphere
Management is very understanding of workers with families 
Lots of potential to advance
Helping students get jobs and change their lives
cons: None that I can think of.  We have a goals to hit, just worry about hitting the goals.

pros:
Great work environment!

 Management is always looking for ways to improve the school and to provide different things for the student. 

Forward thinking attitude
cons:
Health benefits aren't great.
Have to work different schedules through-out the week
Trying to get ideas for management to consider is hard.

pros: Liked interviewing students and learning more about them. Liked team approach and goal motivation
cons: No real training. Senior reps were out for themselves and didn't care about back stabbing.

review_title: This company is unethical and a horrible place to work
pros: I enjoyed working with my students because I'm a people person.
cons: But it felt awful to sign them for this school with a massive bill that they'll never pay off, knowing that they would have difficulty getting a job after graduation. The admissions team is salesy and aggressive. Students were regularly lied to and management was awful.

pros: Great building to be in.  Good teachers, The best wording about how to do a job.
cons: I dont have any cons about working here. everything is awesome and friendly.

pros: Co-workers, maybe we all are in the same boat
cons: President is a joke. Does not care about employee's and students. The CEO does not know what he is doing. They had a great president in Lynnwood and got rid or her. They should had may her the CEO. Stay away from this company and a employee of student.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Canyon Country, CA
pros: Good programs in growing careers. Students who are self activated do very well. Family environment among faculty and staff.
cons: Things change very quickly and for profit educations is getting less support.

pros: Great team, independence, paid holidays, overtime opportunities
cons: No job security, poor management

job_title: Teller in West Valley City, UT
pros: Very laid back sales environment. Allot of turn over. Start up company for admissions. Allot of changes occuring daily.
cons: Did not get allot of coaching weekly. Dials all day long.

review_title: Working at Charter College was a poor educational experiance
pros:
Working with people that are trying to change their life.
Excellent co-workers
cons:
Management could care less about the employee.
Very restrictive on how you set up your class room...even the computer screens are secured down so you cant adjust them.

pros: The paycheck was nice and steady. There were many interesting people I met via the student community.
cons: The practices are deceptive and corrupt for students and employees. I was told not to list my college degrees on my employee profile because they didn't want to deal with the paperwork.

review_title: High pressure sales position.  For profit education is very different than traditional education.
pros:
Competitive salary
Opportunity for additional income with bonus structure
cons:
Corrupt industry
High turnover
Encouraged students to go into debt loads they can't handle.
Industry preys on poor and desperate

review_title: Ok job, management needs some help
pros: Its a job, and some of the people were great.
cons: Favoritism, pay, benefits, company has weak senior management.

job_title: Career Service Officer in Oxnard, CA
pros: I absolutely loved my coworkers. They were so kind and welcoming.
cons: The benefits for a family were very expensive. Also, the hourly pay was less than I was hoping for.

job_title: Admissions Assistant to Director of Admissions in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Easily approachable upper management and positive work environment.
cons: No structure and inexperienced management.

pros: Helping the students be successful was great.
cons: Too much focus on admission numbers.

job_title: Lead Pharmacy Technician Instructor in Reno, NV
pros: Interactive student success coaching, class preparation, curriculum enhancement and  provide extra educational assistance to students was enriching part of the job.
cons: Student retention could be challenging.

job_title: Allied Health Adjunct Faculty in Anchorage, AK
pros: It's an awesome place to work, the Program Director and Co-workers are always very helpful.
cons: There are no Cons to working for Charter College.

pros: The money was good the time off was as expected
